title: Liverpool fan who displayed racist Divock Origi banner identified by police

Police say they have identified the fan who displayed a racist banner depicting Divock Origi ahead of Liverpool's Champions League win over Genk.

Fans were seen unfurling an obscene banner, depicting a mocked-up naked Origi with an abnormally large penis, next to the Champions League trophy at the game in Belgium on Wednesday.

Liverpool confirmed they sought to have the banner removed as soon as they became aware of it - branding it "highly offensive and inappropriate".

And now Merseyside Police have confirmed that they worked with the local authorities in order to identify a suspect, and that cops in Belgium are now investigating.

The statement from Merseyside Police read: "We can confirm Merseyside Police officers assisting local police at the Genk vs Liverpool fixture on Wednesday night (October 23) removed a banner in the Liverpool supporters' section.

(Image: Kieran McManus/BPI/REX)

"We worked with Liverpool FC and the local authorities to identify the person responsible, and the local police in Belgium are now conducting an investigation."

Uefa have not yet commented on the matter but could take action against Liverpool.

In May 2018 Bayern Munich were fined £21,650 for an 'illicit banner' that was on display in their Champions League semi-final against Real Madrid .

Liverpool released a statement on the night of the game condemning the banner.

(Image: Michael Zemanek/BPI/REX)

A Liverpool spokesperson said: "Liverpool Football Club condemns the offensive banner displayed in our section of the ground, prior to kick-off.

"To be clear, the image used perpetuated a racist stereotype. This is completely unacceptable.

"We acted swiftly to have the banner removed and we are now working with the local authorities and stadium team in Genk to identify those responsible.

"Any subsequent action will be taken in keeping with our sanctions process."

(Image: Twitter)

The controversy came amid a series of high-profile racist incidents in football in recent weeks.

Manchester United issued an indefinite ban to a supporter over racist abuse aimed at Liverpool defender Trent Alexander-Arnold during Sunday's 1-1 draw at old Trafford.

That came after England's players were subject to shocking abuse during their Euro 2020 qualifier with Belgium last week.

Non-league Haringey Borough also walked off the pitch during their FA Cup clash with Yeovil after their players were abused.
description: Merseyside Police have worked with authorities in Belgium after obscene banner was unfurled at Genk Champions League clash
